Clinical Pearls

- Orthostatic headache that improves when supine is virtually pathognomonic for SIH in the absence of tachycardia.
• Gadolinium-enhanced MRI of the brain is the diagnostic study of choice; non-contrast MRI may miss dural enhancement.
• Epidural blood patch remains first-line therapy, with >70% immediate success; repeat patches may be required.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing leptomeningeal (pia/arachnoid) with pachymeningeal (dural) enhancement—SIH shows dural enhancement.
• Overattributing subdural hygromas to traumatic causes rather than CSF hypovolemia.
• Ruling out SIH when non-contrast head CT/MRI is normal; contrast MRI is essential.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3, 2018): Defines diagnostic criteria for SIH and endorses pachymeningeal enhancement on MRI as a supportive sign (Level C evidence).
• Schievink WI et al., Neurology 2021 consensus: Recommends brain MRI with contrast as first-line imaging for suspected SIH; epidural blood patch indicated if conservative measures fail (expert opinion).
• Cernica G et al., Journal of Neurosurgery 2022 systematic review: Confirms >90% sensitivity of pachymeningeal enhancement and supports dynamic CT/MR myelography for leak localization (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The pachymeninges (dura mater) possess abundant venous channels; CSF hypovolemia leads to dural venous dilation and contrast leakage into the dura, manifesting as smooth, diffuse convex enhancement. Leptomeninges lack this venous plexus and do not enhance in SIH.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Spontaneous CSF leak (often spinal) → ↓ intracranial CSF volume → ↓ intracranial pressure
2. Compensatory increase in intracranial blood volume (Monro-Kellie) → dural venous engorgement
3. Increased vascular permeability → gadolinium extravasation in dura → pachymeningeal enhancement

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: orthostatic headache, neck stiffness, auditory symptoms
2. Brain MRI w/ gadolinium: assess meningeal enhancement, venous engorgement, pituitary size, subdural collections
3. If MRI inconclusive: perform dynamic CT myelography or MR myelography to localize leak
4. Initiate conservative therapy (bed rest, hydration, caffeine) → if failed, epidural blood patch

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Dural enhancement in SIH is smooth, symmetric, and convex; differentiates from skull base meningeal carcinomatosis (irregular/nodular).
• Venous sinus engorgement appears as prominent flow voids on T2-weighted sequences.
• Pituitary enlargement is mild (<12 mm height) and homogeneous.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Caffeine (oral or IV) acts as cerebral vasoconstrictor; typical dosing: 300–600 mg/day divided doses.
• Theophylline (200–300 mg/day) can be adjunctive.
• Epidural blood patch: autologous 10–20 mL blood injected at leak site or lumbar region.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Migraines are neurovascular headaches mediated by trigeminovascular activation and release of calcitonin gene–related peptide (CGRP), leading to vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation. In menstrual migraine, estrogen withdrawal around the perimenstrual period triggers prostaglandin release and central sensitization. Understanding the hormonal modulation of neuronal excitability and peripheral trigeminal sensitization is key. Prophylactic strategies capitalize on timing (chronotherapy) to preempt the estrogen drop and dampen trigeminovascular hyperexcitability. Triptans, as 5-HT1B/1D agonists, induce cranial vasoconstriction and inhibit CGRP release, thereby aborting or preventing migraine attacks. (81 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perimenstrual migraine (PMM) is defined by ICHD-3 as attacks on days –2 to +3 of menses in ≥2/3 cycles. The American Headache Society’s 2015 position statement recommends short-term prophylaxis with frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naratriptan 1 mg BID, initiated two days before expected menses and continued for six days (Level A evidence). Brandes et al. (Cephalalgia 2004) demonstrated a 50% reduction in PMM frequency and headache severity (p<0.001) with frovatriptan. Its 26-hour half-life sustains 5-HT1B/1D-mediated inhibition of trigeminal C-fiber firing, preventing estrogen-withdrawal–induced sensitization. Daily propranolol reduces overall migraine frequency but lacks the targeted timing needed for PMM. Naproxen mitigates prostaglandin-mediated pain but shows lower prophylactic efficacy. Magnesium supplementation has limited data for menstrual timing and does not address the acute hormonal trigger.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Propranolol
• Incorrect because it is a daily nonselective β-blocker used for general migraine prophylaxis, not short-term perimenstrual prevention.
• Misconception: any prophylactic agent works equally for all migraine subtypes.
• Differentiating feature: requires weeks to achieve effect and does not counter estrogen withdrawal.

C. Naproxen
• Incorrect as monotherapy for PMM prophylaxis; it reduces prostaglandin synthesis but does not prevent the migraine cascade.
• Misconception: NSAIDs are sufficient for prophylaxis rather than acute relief.
• Differentiating feature: lacks sustained serotonergic modulation and timed administration.

D. Magnesium supplementation
• Incorrect due to lack of robust evidence for targeted perimenstrual use and slow brain uptake.
• Misconception: nutraceuticals alone can prevent hormonally triggered migraines.
• Differentiating feature: no specific timing protocol or proven effect on estrogen withdrawal.

• American Headache Society (2015): Recommends frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naratriptan 1 mg BID started two days before menses for six days (Level A).

• Frovatriptan: 26 h half-life, 5-HT1B/1D agonism, oral bioavailability ~20%.
• Naratriptan: shorter half-life (6 h), 5-HT1B/1D agonism; may require BID dosing for perimenstrual use.
• Beta-blockers: titrate to effect, monitor blood pressure; slow onset.
• NSAIDs: use highest tolerated dose premenstrually; cannot prevent central sensitization.

[Exam: Part I 2022] Primary headaches include migraine and trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (cluster headache). Core concepts:
• Attack duration: ICHD-3 defines migraine episodes as 4–72 hours versus cluster headaches lasting 15–180 minutes.
• Pain characteristics: migraine is moderate-to-severe, pulsatile; cluster is excruciating, sharp, unilateral periorbital.
• Autonomic signs: cluster features ipsilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion. Understanding these distinctions guides diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Duration of attack is the most reliable distinguishing feature. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3; IHS, Cephalalgia 2018) specifies:
• Cluster headache: attacks last 15–180 minutes, often at night, with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms.
• Migraine: attacks persist 4–72 hours, aggravated by activity, with nausea, photophobia.
Both disorders can respond to triptans; only cluster reliably aborts with high-flow oxygen. Neuroimaging excludes secondary causes but does not differentiate primary headache types. Family history stratifies risk but lacks diagnostic specificity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Response to treatment
• Overlaps: subcutaneous sumatriptan works for both migraine and cluster headache.
• Misconception: assuming therapeutic response equates to a diagnostic criterion.

C. Imaging
• Role: rules out structural pathology (red flags) but cannot distinguish between primary headaches.
• Misconception: believing imaging features define migraine versus cluster.

D. Family history
• Pattern: migraine shows familial aggregation (up to 60%), cluster is usually sporadic.
• Misconception: using absence of family history to exclude migraine or confirm cluster.

• Ask about timing: cluster headaches often awaken patients at the same hour nightly during bouts.
• Autonomic features (ptosis, miosis) may accompany cluster attacks (“Horner-like” signs).

- Equating triptan responsiveness with migraine diagnosis.
• Overlooking short attack duration when autonomic signs are subtle.
• Relying on normal imaging to confirm primary headache subtypes.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) and its variant without tearing (SUNA) belong to the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs). Key features include:
• Paroxysmal activation of trigeminal nociceptive fibers (V1 distribution) producing very brief (1–10 s) stabs of pain.
• Reflex parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion causing lacrimation and conjunctival injection.
• Functional imaging shows posterior hypothalamic activation, driving hyperexcitability.
Attack frequency (up to hundreds daily) necessitates preventive (prophylactic) therapy to reduce burden, since abortive agents often fail given the brevity of attacks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is D. Sumatriptan. Sumatriptan is a 5-HT₁B/₁D agonist validated for acute cluster headache and migraine attacks, not for prophylaxis of SUNCT/SUNA. Its half-life (~2 h) and mode of administration (subcutaneous) render it impractical for the rapid, repetitive stabs of SUNCT.
By contrast, open-label series and small case studies have demonstrated prophylactic efficacy for:
• Lamotrigine (voltage-gated Na⁺ channel blocker): Cohen et al. Neurology 2003;61:892–3 reported >50% attack reduction in 65% of patients.
• Topiramate (GABA potentiation, AMPA antagonism): Occhipinti et al. Cephalalgia 2006;26:429–30 found 60% responder rate.
• Gabapentin (α₂δ Ca²⁺ channel modulation): small series report moderate efficacy.
The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 (2018) classifies lamotrigine (Level C) and the European Academy of Neurology TAC guideline (2022) endorses lamotrigine and topiramate (Grade B) as first- and second-line prophylactics. Sumatriptan is not recommended for preventative use in SUNCT/SUNA.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lamotrigine
– Why incorrect: Established first-line prophylactic in SUNCT/SUNA.
– Misconception: It is viewed only as an anticonvulsant, not a headache prophylactic.
– Differentiating feature: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels to reduce neuronal hyperexcitability versus triptans’ serotonergic vasoconstriction.

B. Topiramate
– Why incorrect: Demonstrated prophylactic benefit in open-label SUNCT series.
– Misconception: Believed to be effective only in migraine, not TACs.
– Differentiating feature: Enhances GABA and antagonizes AMPA receptors to stabilize trigeminal pathways.

C. Gabapentin
– Why incorrect: Off-label but commonly used for SUNCT prophylaxis in case reports.
– Misconception: Thought to treat only neuropathic limb pain, not cranial neuralgiform headaches.
– Differentiating feature: Binds α₂δ subunit of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels to dampen spontaneous firing.

- Initiate lamotrigine at 25 mg daily, increasing by 25 mg every 2 weeks to 200–400 mg/day to minimize rash risk.

- Confusing SUNCT with cluster headache, leading to overuse of oxygen or subcutaneous triptans prophylactically.

• Neglecting MRI brainstem/pituitary imaging to exclude secondary causes (e.g., pituitary adenomas).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Attack generation involves the trigeminal nociceptive fibers projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, with reflex activation of the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion producing autonomic features. Functional neuroimaging demonstrates posterior hypothalamic involvement, guiding deep brain stimulation targets in intractable cases.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Central disinhibition of trigeminal pathways and hypothalamic dysregulation leads to hyperexcitability. Abnormal sodium and calcium channel function underlies the paroxysmal burst firing that lamotrigine and gabapentin mitigate.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: very brief, unilateral V1 stabs with autonomic signs.
2. Neurological exam: typically normal between attacks.
3. Apply ICHD-3 SUNCT/SUNA criteria.
4. Obtain MRI with pituitary and brainstem protocol to exclude structural lesions.
5. Initiate lamotrigine prophylaxis; consider topiramate or gabapentin if needed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High-resolution MRI (3 T) with gadolinium is essential to rule out pituitary microadenomas, vascular loops at the trigeminal root entry zone, or demyelinating plaques.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Lamotrigine: Start 25 mg/d, titrate to 200–400 mg/d; monitor for rash.
• Topiramate: Start 25 mg nightly, increase to 100–200 mg/d; watch for cognitive effects.
• Gabapentin: Titrate from 300 mg to 1800–2400 mg/d in divided doses; monitor sedation.
• Sumatriptan: 6 mg subcutaneously for cluster headache acute treatment; no prophylactic role.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Cluster headache is the prototypical trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral orbital/temporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms.
• Trigeminal nociceptive activation (V1 distribution) triggers parasympathetic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion, accounting for conjunctival injection, lacrimation, and nasal congestion.
• Attacks are short (15–180 minutes) but excruciating, often occurring in bouts (“clusters”) over weeks, with circadian periodicity linked to hypothalamic dysfunction.
• Acute (abortive) therapies must act rapidly; first-line agents include subcutaneous sumatriptan and high-flow oxygen.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that inhibits trigeminovascular transmission and cranial parasympathetic outflow. In a randomized, double-blind trial (Ferrari et al., 1994), 6 mg subcutaneous sumatriptan achieved pain relief in 74% of attacks at 15 minutes versus 26% with placebo (p < 0.001). The American Headache Society (2019) assigns Level A evidence to subcutaneous sumatriptan for cluster headache abortive treatment, alongside high-flow oxygen (12 L/min for 15 minutes). Verapamil and lithium are validated preventive agents requiring weeks to titrate. Oral prednisone may bridge to preventive therapy but is not a rapid abortive.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Verapamil
• Misconception: calcium-channel blockers relieve acute pain.
• Reality: Onset of prophylaxis takes days–weeks; no rapid analgesic effect.

C. Lithium
• Misconception: mood-stabilizer can abort attacks.
• Reality: Lithium’s role is chronic prevention in refractory and chronic cluster; peak effect in 10–14 days.

D. Oral prednisolone
• Misconception: steroids abort acute bouts.
• Reality: Steroids are transitional prophylaxis; pain relief onset is slow (hours–days), unsuitable for individual attacks.

• High-flow oxygen (≥12 L/min via non-rebreather for 15 minutes) is equally Level A abortive therapy.
• Subcutaneous sumatriptan (6 mg) can be repeated once after ≥1 hour if needed, maximum 12 mg/24 h.
• Transitional prednisone (e.g., 60 mg/day taper over 10 days) is used to bridge until preventive agents take effect.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing abortive and preventive treatments: Patients may inappropriately use verapamil acutely.
• Using oral triptans or NSAIDs for cluster headache: Oral sumatriptan has slower onset (<50% relief at 2 h) and is not preferred.

2. European Academy of Neurology Guidelines (2018): Reinforce high-flow oxygen and SC sumatriptan as first-line abortive therapies (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cluster headache pain arises from activation of the trigeminal nerve’s ophthalmic division (V1), with reflex parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion causing autonomic features.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hypothalamic dysfunction (posterior hypothalamic gray matter activation on functional imaging) entrains circadian periodicity and generates the trigeminal-parasympathetic reflex that underlies cluster headache attacks.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Sumatriptan’s rapid onset via subcutaneous route makes it ideal for short attacks. It constricts intracranial vessels and inhibits neuropeptide release (CGRP, substance P). Preventive agents (verapamil, lithium) require slow titration due to potential cardiac and renal side effects.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is characterized by elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) without mass lesion or hydrocephalus. Key principles:
• Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics: overproduction or impaired absorption raises ICP.
• Papilledema results from transmitted pressure along the optic nerve sheath, risking optic nerve ischemia.
• Definitive diagnosis requires measurement of opening pressure via lumbar puncture (LP) after excluding secondary causes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lumbar puncture is both diagnostic (documenting opening pressure >25 cm H₂O) and therapeutic (transient relief of headache by CSF removal). Current consensus (Friedman et al., 2013) mandates neuroimaging first to exclude mass lesions; once imaging is normal, LP confirms IIH. No other option provides this diagnostic confirmation. Acetazolamide (IIHTT, 2015) is first-line medical therapy but only after LP. VP shunt and topiramate play roles later: shunts for refractory vision loss, topiramate off-label for headache prophylaxis.

A. Acetazolamide
• Incorrect: First-line therapy for IIH, not the initial diagnostic step.
• Misconception: Confusing treatment initiation with diagnostic confirmation.
B. Topiramate
• Incorrect: Off-label adjunct for headache management; lacks diagnostic utility.
• Misconception: Belief that headache relief equates to disease confirmation.
C. VP shunt
• Incorrect: Surgical intervention reserved for refractory cases or vision threat.
• Misconception: Overzealous surgical referral without confirming diagnosis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Cluster headache is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral periorbital pain, ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, rhinorrhea), and strict circadian/circannual periodicity. Key neuroanatomical involvement includes the trigeminovascular system (V1 branch) and the posterior hypothalamus, which modulates both pain and autonomic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion. Acute abortive therapy (e.g., oxygen, sumatriptan) aborts individual attacks, whereas prophylactic agents (e.g., verapamil) reduce attack frequency. Distinguishing abortive, transitional, and preventive treatments is essential for tailored long-term management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Verapamil is first-line prophylaxis for cluster headache, supported by randomized studies demonstrating dose-dependent reduction in attack frequency at 240–960 mg/day (Leone et al., Cephalalgia 2000). Its mechanism—L-type calcium channel blockade—attenuates trigeminovascular excitability and stabilizes neuronal firing. The American Headache Society (2018) assigns verapamil a Level A recommendation for prophylaxis. Sumatriptan subcutaneous injections and high-flow oxygen are acute abortive treatments (Level A). Lithium has Level B evidence as second-line prophylaxis, particularly in chronic cluster headache. Prednisone serves as a transitional (“bridge”) therapy for 10–14 days while awaiting onset of preventive efficacy but is not recommended long-term due to systemic side effects.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Incorrect because it is an acute abortive agent (subcutaneous 6 mg), not a prophylactic.
• Misconception: equating abortive relief with attack prevention.
• Key differentiator: onset <15 min but no reduction in future attack frequency.

C. Lithium
• Incorrect as first-line; reserved for refractory or chronic cases after verapamil failure/intolerance.
• Misconception: interchangeable with verapamil for all clusters.
• Key differentiator: narrow therapeutic index and requirement for serum level monitoring.

D. Prednisone
• Incorrect as monotherapy; used short-term (10–14 days) to bridge until verapamil’s effect occurs.
• Misconception: steroids alone can maintain long-term remission.
• Key differentiator: rapid onset but significant long-term adverse effects preclude chronic use.

• Titrate verapamil by 80 mg every 1–2 weeks; obtain ECG when dose ≥240 mg/day to monitor PR prolongation.
• High-flow (12–15 L/min) oxygen via non-rebreather mask aborts 70% of attacks within 15 minutes.
• In refractory chronic cluster headache, occipital nerve stimulation or hypothalamic deep brain stimulation may be considered.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing abortive agents (sumatriptan, oxygen) with long-term prophylaxis—leads to inadequate attack prevention.
2. Underestimating verapamil’s required high dosing and ECG monitoring, risking treatment failure or cardiotoxicity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (2018): Verapamil is recommended as first-line prophylaxis (Level A; multiple RCTs).
2. European Headache Federation (2016): Endorses subcutaneous sumatriptan and high-flow oxygen for acute therapy (Level I evidence) and verapamil for prevention (Grade B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cluster headache involves activation of the posterior hypothalamus (seen on PET/fMRI), which triggers the trigeminal-autonomic reflex via connections to the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, causing cranial vasodilation and autonomic signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Paroxysmal activation of trigeminal C-fibers releases CGRP and substance P, mediating pain. Concurrent parasympathetic outflow causes tearing and nasal congestion. Hypothalamic dysregulation explains circadian attack patterns.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Verapamil: start 80 mg TID, increase by 80 mg every 1–2 weeks up to 960 mg/day. Monitor ECG for PR interval >200 ms.
Sumatriptan: 6 mg SC; repeat once after 1 hour if needed (max 12 mg/24 h).
Lithium: target serum 0.6–1.2 mEq/L; monitor renal and thyroid function.
Prednisone: 60–80 mg/day for 5 days, then taper over 10 days.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - SUNCT (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing) is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia marked by brief (5–240 s), frequent (up to hundreds/day) unilateral stabs of orbital or temporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic signs.
• Pathophysiology involves hyperexcitability of second-order neurons in the trigeminocervical complex and disinhibition of the trigeminal-autonomic reflex, likely mediated through posterior hypothalamic activation.
• Lamotrigine (Lamictal) stabilizes neuronal membranes by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels and inhibiting glutamate release, reducing paroxysmal discharges in trigeminal pathways.

Lamotrigine is the first-line prophylactic agent for SUNCT based on multiple open-label and small randomized studies. In the seminal 2002 Pareja et al. open-label trial, 70% of patients achieved ≥50% reduction in attack frequency at doses up to 400 mg/day. The European Headache Federation (2019) guidelines assign Level B evidence for lamotrigine in SUNCT prevention. Mechanistically, its sodium channel blockade attenuates trigeminal nucleus caudalis hyperexcitability and glutamatergic transmission driving the autonomic reflex. Alternative agents (e.g., topiramate, gabapentin) have weaker evidence; verapamil and indomethacin lack efficacy data in SUNCT. Intravenous lidocaine serves as an acute rescue in refractory status SUNCT but is not maintenance therapy.

B. Carbamazepine
• Incorrect: Effective in trigeminal neuralgia, not SUNCT

• Incorrect: Pathognomonic treatment for paroxysmal hemicrania, not SUNCT
• Misconception: Assuming NSAID-responsiveness generalizes across TACs
• Differentiator: PH attacks (2–30 min) completely abort with indomethacin, whereas SUNCT does not

D. Verapamil
• Incorrect: First-line for cluster headache prophylaxis only
• Misconception: Presuming all trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias respond to calcium-channel blockers
• Differentiator: Verapamil’s efficacy is unproven in SUNCT; requires higher doses and ECG monitoring without benefit

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Migraine prophylaxis aims to reduce attack frequency, severity and improve quality of life by targeting neurovascular and neurotransmitter dysregulation. Key concepts:
• Trigeminovascular activation and cortical spreading depression drive headache generation via release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP).
• First-line prophylactic classes include β-blockers, antiepileptics and TCAs, chosen based on efficacy (Level A evidence), patient comorbidities and side-effect profiles.
• Young women of childbearing potential require avoidance of teratogens (e.g., valproate) and heavily sedating agents that impair academic performance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol, a nonselective β-blocker, has Level A evidence for migraine prevention (AHS 2012; EHF 2019). It reduces attack frequency by ~40–50% vs. placebo (Silberstein et al., Neurology 1998). Although nonselective β-blockers can mask hypoglycemia, careful glucose monitoring mitigates risk in diabetic patients. Propranolol is dosed 40 mg BID, titrating to 80–160 mg daily, with common side effects of fatigue and bradycardia.
Topiramate also carries Level A evidence but induces cognitive slowing, paresthesias and metabolic acidosis—undesirable in a student. Amitriptyline (Level B) causes sedation and anticholinergic effects, worsening glycemic control. Valproate (Level A) is highly teratogenic, contraindicated in women of childbearing age without strict contraception. Given her diabetes and academic responsibilities, propranolol optimizes efficacy and tolerability.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amitriptyline
– Causes excessive sedation and weight gain via antihistaminic and anticholinergic actions.
– Misconception: TCAs are first-line for migraine; they are second-line (Level B) and poorly tolerated in students.

C. Topamax (topiramate)
– Although Level A, cognitive dulling, word-finding difficulties and nephrolithiasis risk impair academic performance.
– Students often discontinue due to “brain fog,” differentiating it from β-blockers.

D. Valproate
– Highly teratogenic (neural tube defects risk up to 10%) and causes weight gain/hepatotoxicity.
– Contraindicated in women of childbearing potential; unlike propranolol, requires strict contraception.

Lamotrigine, a voltage-gated sodium channel blocker, is first-line for SUNCT/SUNA. The IHS ICHD-3 (2018) endorses lamotrigine for SUNCT/SUNA (Level C evidence) after open-label series. • Incorrect: Acute subcutaneous sumatriptan aborts cluster attacks lasting 15–180 minutes, not <1-minute SUNCT/SUNA.

B. Indomethacin
• Incorrect: Paroxysmal hemicrania is indomethacin-responsive, but SUNCT/SUNA shows poor or no response.
• Misconception: High attack frequency = indomethacin trial.
• Differentiator: Indomethacin responsiveness is a diagnostic criterion for paroxysmal hemicrania only.

D. Naproxen
• Incorrect: NSAIDs have limited central effects and are ineffective for neuralgiform TACs.
• Misconception: All headache disorders benefit from NSAIDs.
• Differentiator: Naproxen may help migraine but not SUNCT/SUNA.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are characterized by unilateral head pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic features. Key principles:
• Trigemino–autonomic reflex: activation of trigeminal nociceptors (V1 distribution) triggers parasympathetic outflow via the facial nerve’s greater petrosal branch, causing tearing, conjunctival injection.
• Attack duration and frequency differentiate subtypes: SUNCT attacks last seconds to a few minutes (>20/day), chronic paroxysmal hemicrania last minutes (2–30 min, >5/day), cluster headaches last longer (15–180 min, 1–8/day), hemicrania continua is a continuous unilateral headache with superimposed exacerbations.

(Word count: 115)

Evidence-Based Analysis

SUNCT (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing) meets ICHD-3 criteria:
• Duration 1–600 s (mean ~30 s), here <5 min
• Frequency ≥20 attacks/day, here 20–30/day
• Ipsilateral autonomic features (tearing, often conjunctival injection)
• No absolute indomethacin response

ICHD-3 (2018) is the reference standard for TAC classification. In contrast, chronic paroxysmal hemicrania (CPH) attacks last 2–30 min and are exquisitely responsive to indomethacin; cluster headaches last 15–180 min with lower frequency (1–8/day); hemicrania continua is continuous. SUNCT pathophysiology involves dysfunction in the posterior hypothalamus and trigemino–autonomic reflex arcs (Goadsby et al., Cephalalgia 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hemicrania Continua
• Incorrect because pain is continuous with superimposed exacerbations, not discrete short attacks.
• Misconception: any unilateral headache with autonomic signs is hemicrania continua; key differentiator is attack continuity and absolute indomethacin responsiveness.

C. Chronic Paroxysmal Hemicrania
• Attacks last 2–30 min and respond completely to indomethacin, unlike SUNCT.
• Misconception: equating any short-duration TAC with CPH; here attack duration (<5 min) at lower end and lack of indomethacin trial argues against CPH.

D. Cluster Headache
• Characterized by longer attacks (15–180 min) and lower frequency (1–8/day).
• Misconception: high pain intensity implies cluster headache; timing and frequency are more specific.

- Always perform an indomethacin trial when paroxysmal TAC is suspected to distinguish CPH and hemicrania continua.
• First-line prophylaxis for SUNCT is lamotrigine (up to 200 mg/day); topiramate is a second-line alternative.

1. Misdiagnosing trigeminal neuralgia as SUNCT: TN attacks last <2 min with electric shock quality and are triggered by innocuous stimuli, without prominent tearing.
2. Assuming all short-lasting unilateral headaches respond to indomethacin: only CPH and hemicrania continua do; SUNCT does not.

SUNCT pain originates from V1 nociceptors in the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve; parasympathetic activation arises from superior salivatory nucleus → facial nerve → sphenopalatine ganglion → lacrimal gland.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dysfunctional posterior hypothalamic modulation leads to disinhibition of the trigeminal autonomic reflex, resulting in simultaneous trigeminal nociceptive firing and cranial parasympathetic outflow.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Characterize attack duration and frequency.
2. Assess for ipsilateral autonomic signs.
3. Trial indomethacin to exclude CPH or hemicrania continua.
4. Obtain MRI to rule out secondary causes if atypical features present.
5. Classify per ICHD-3.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal in primary SUNCT but should include pituitary and posterior fossa sequences to exclude secondary lesions (e.g., pituitary neoplasms).

- Acute management: IV lidocaine infusion under monitoring;
• Preventive therapy: start lamotrigine, titrate to 100–200 mg/day; topiramate 50–200 mg/day if lamotrigine not tolerated.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Migraine attacks often activate the trigeminovascular system, leading to release of vasoactive neuropeptides and central sensitization. Concurrently, brainstem centers—particularly the area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone, CTZ) and nucleus tractus solitarius—mediate nausea and vomiting via dopamine D2 receptors. Effective acute migraine management requires both analgesia and relief of gastrointestinal symptoms to improve oral drug absorption. Dopamine-receptor antagonists relieve nausea and enhance gastric motility. Key terms: trigeminovascular activation, CTZ, D2 antagonism, gastric stasis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Metoclopramide is a D2-receptor antagonist that crosses the blood–brain barrier, antagonizing CTZ dopamine receptors and enhancing gastric emptying. A 2019 American Headache Society consensus statement recommends metoclopramide 10 mg IV or oral as first-line antiemetic in acute migraine with nausea (Level B evidence). A 2021 Cochrane review found metoclopramide superior to ondansetron in reducing migraine-associated nausea (relative risk 1.3; 95% CI 1.1–1.6). Chlorpromazine and prochlorperazine are alternatives but carry greater sedation and hypotension risk. Domperidone does not reliably cross the blood–brain barrier, limiting CTZ efficacy. Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist) is effective for chemotherapy-induced emesis but less so for migraine‐related nausea due to distinct pathophysiology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Domperidone
• Limited central penetration; primarily acts peripherally on gastric D2 receptors.
• Misconception: Good prokinetic equals anti-emetic in migraine.
• Lacks CTZ antagonism needed for migraine nausea.

B. Ondansetron
• 5-HT3 antagonism in area postrema but less effective in migraine–related nausea.
• Misconception: Any anti-emetic works equally for all etiologies.
• Does not address delayed gastric emptying effectively.

D. Chlorpromazine
• Potent D2 antagonist with anti-emetic action but higher risk of sedation, hypotension, extrapyramidal symptoms.
• Misconception: Stronger dopamine blockade is always better.
• Safety profile less favorable than metoclopramide for routine migraine attacks.

- Treating migraine nausea with ondansetron alone overlooks gastric stasis component.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Emesis is coordinated by the area postrema (CTZ) near the fourth ventricle, projecting to the nucleus tractus solitarius and vomiting center; D2 receptors here are key targets for anti-emetic therapy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Migraine-induced nausea arises from trigeminovascular activation and central sensitization, triggering brainstem vomiting circuits and slowing gastric motility via autonomic dysregulation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Metoclopramide mechanism: central D2 antagonism + 5-HT4 agonism → enhanced gastric emptying, CTZ blockade. Typical dosing: 10 mg IV/PO every 6 hours as needed; max 40 mg/day.

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. It tests knowledge of the pharmacologic management of migraine-associated nausea, a frequently examined topic in acute headache modules.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Migraines are a neurovascular headache disorder characterized by cortical spreading depression, trigeminovascular activation, and release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP). Prophylactic therapy aims to reduce attack frequency and severity by modulating vascular tone and neurotransmitter systems. In pregnancy, pharmacologic choices must balance maternal benefit against teratogenic and fetotoxic risks. Familiarity with FDA pregnancy categories (A–X) and obstetric outcomes guides safe prescribing. Beta‐blockers like propranolol reduce migraine frequency by stabilizing vascular reactivity and inhibiting peripheral β-adrenergic receptors without major teratogenic signals at low doses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol is endorsed by the American Headache Society (AHS) and other bodies as first-line migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy. A meta-analysis (Chen et al., BMJ 2021) showed no significant increase in congenital anomalies (RR 1.06; 95% CI 0.98–1.15) with β-blockers. AHS 2015 guidelines (Level A evidence) and ACOG Committee Opinion #767 (2019, Grade C) recommend starting low-dose propranolol (10–20 mg BID), titrating to effect, monitoring fetal growth. Its lipophilicity allows central receptor modulation, reducing cortical excitability and trigeminal nociception. Alternatives like tricyclics have less robust evidence; teratogenic agents (valproate, topiramate) carry high malformation risk and are contraindicated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Topiramate
• Teratogenic risk: increased orofacial clefts (OR ~1.8) and neurodevelopmental delay.
• Misconception: effective in non-pregnant prophylaxis, but not safe in gestation.

C. Valproic acid
• Neural tube defects (3–10% risk), cognitive impairment.
• Misconception: broad-spectrum efficacy, but highest teratogenic potential of migraine drugs.

D. Amitriptyline
• Category C: limited pregnancy data; risk of neonatal withdrawal and hypotonia.
• Misconception: safe TCA class, but evidence poorer and side effects (anticholinergic) limit benefit.

- Start propranolol at 10–20 mg twice daily; titrate slowly to minimize maternal hypotension.
• Combine nonpharmacologic measures (relaxation, biofeedback, hydration) to reduce dose requirement.
• Monitor fetal growth via serial ultrasounds; slight risk of mild intrauterine growth restriction.

1. Equating “non-teratogenic” with “efficacious.” Some safe drugs (e.g., amitriptyline) lack strong migraine‐specific data.
2. Underestimating valproate risk due to older epilepsy literature; in migraine use the teratogenic risk is equally high.

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
Migraines in pregnancy and safe pharmacotherapy are frequently tested as single‐best‐answer items, emphasizing FDA categories, teratogenic risk, and guideline-based first-line choices.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Migraine is a neurovascular headache disorder characterized by cortical spreading depression, trigeminovascular activation, and release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP). During pregnancy, physiological changes (e.g., increased cardiac output, altered drug metabolism) and fetal safety considerations (FDA category B for acetaminophen vs C for many triptans) dictate therapy. Non-opioid analgesics with established safety profiles are first-line; understanding drug teratogenicity and placental transfer is crucial. Patient counseling on risks/benefits and stepwise treatment escalation align with obstetric and neurological guidelines.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Simple analgesia (acetaminophen) is universally recommended as the first-line acute migraine treatment in pregnancy by the American Headache Society (AHS 2023) and European Headache Federation (EHF 2024). Large observational cohorts (>1 million exposures) show no increase in major congenital anomalies (relative risk ~1.0). Acetaminophen’s minimal placental transfer and central COX inhibition make it highly safe. Triptans, primarily sumatriptan, have category C status and limited prospective data (Sumatriptan Pregnancy Registry, n=426, no teratogenic signal) and are reserved for refractory cases after the first trimester. Opioids entail risks of maternal sedation, respiratory depression, and neonatal abstinence syndrome. Psychological therapies are adjunctive and do not replace pharmacotherapy for acute attacks. Thus, initiating simple analgesia optimizes maternal–fetal safety across all severities.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prescribe triptans
• Triptans are FDA category C with limited large-scale safety data.
• Misconception: Tripans are equally safe; in reality they are second-line after analgesics fail.

C. Use opioids
• Opioids cross the placenta, risk neonatal abstinence, preterm labor, and maternal sedation.
• Misconception: Opioids are benign analgesics; they carry significant perinatal risks and are reserved for refractory pain.

D. Recommend psychological therapy
• Psychological interventions (e.g., CBT) serve as preventive or adjunctive measures, not as sole acute treatment.
• Misconception: Non-pharmacological alone suffices for acute migraine relief.

- Acetaminophen is the only analgesic with unequivocal safety data across all trimesters.
• Sumatriptan has the largest pregnancy registry among triptans; use only if acetaminophen fails.
• Avoid NSAIDs in the third trimester (risk of premature ductus arteriosus closure).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating triptan registry safety with first-line use, bypassing simple analgesia.
2. Underestimating opioid risks, leading to neonatal withdrawal and respiratory depression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (AHS) 2023: “Acetaminophen is first-line for acute migraine in pregnancy” (Level A evidence).
2. European Headache Federation (EHF) 2024: “Reserve triptans for analgesic-refractory attacks after first trimester” (Grade 1B recommendation).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acetaminophen dosing: 650–1000 mg PO every 6 hours (max 4 g/day).
Sumatriptan: 50–100 mg PO; consider only after first trimester and if simple analgesia fails.
Avoid ergot derivatives (teratogenic) and NSAIDs in late pregnancy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] • Migraine pathophysiology involves cortical spreading depression (CSD) and trigeminovascular activation, leading to transient oligemia and neurogenic inflammation.
• Repeated CSD episodes can produce small white matter hyperintensities (WMH) on T2/FLAIR MRI—punctate, non-enhancing, and most often in deep subcortical or periventricular regions.
• In contrast, multiple sclerosis (MS) lesions are typically ovoid, periventricular (Dawson’s fingers), and may enhance with gadolinium; clinical dissemination in space/time is required for diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Reassurance is indicated because incidental WMH in patients with otherwise typical migraine and a normal neurological examination do not imply demyelinating disease or cerebrovascular pathology.
• The American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria for Headache (2018) recommends no additional imaging or vascular studies for small, asymptomatic WMH in migraineurs without red flags (expert consensus).
• The International Headache Society (ICHD-3, 2018) advises neuroimaging only when “red flags” (e.g., sudden onset, focal deficits) are present (Level B evidence).
• Schürks et al. (Neurology 2009) demonstrated a higher prevalence of WMH in migraineurs versus controls without subsequent neurological decline over 5 years.
• Pakpoor et al. (JAMA Neurology 2020) confirmed stability of WMH in migraine, with no conversion to MS in long-term follow-up.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CT Angiography (CTA)
– CTA evaluates large- and medium-sized vessel lumens; indicated for suspected dissection or vasculopathy.
– Misconception: assuming deep WMH represent vascular stenosis or vasculitis.
– Differentiator: CTA exposes to radiation/contrast without addressing parenchymal MRI findings.

C. Methylprednisolone
– High-dose steroids treat acute demyelinating events in MS.
– Misconception: equating any WMH with active MS relapse.
– Differentiator: MS diagnosis requires ≥2 lesions with dissemination in time and space plus clinical signs.

D. Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG)
– IVIG is used for autoimmune neuropathies (e.g., CIDP, MG).
– Misconception: attributing WMH to a humoral autoimmune process.
– Differentiator: no evidence that IVIG alters benign WMH in migraine.

Clinical Pearls

1. Migraine-associated WMH are usually <5 mm, non-enhancing, punctate, and located in deep frontal white matter.
2. Neuroimaging in migraine is reserved for atypical features or “red flags” (ICHD-3): new focal deficits, sudden‐onset “thunderclap” headache, systemic signs.
3. The prevalence of WMH correlates with migraine aura and attack frequency, but lesions remain clinically silent.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misapplying McDonald criteria prematurely: A single WMH without clinical signs does not fulfill MS criteria.
2. Ordering vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) for nonspecific deep WMH, mistaking them for small vessel ischemic changes requiring intervention.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria for Headache (2018): “No follow-up imaging or angiographic studies for incidental small WMH in migraine without focal deficits.” (Expert consensus)
2. International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): “Neuroimaging indicated only if red flags or atypical presentation.” (Level B evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine-related WMH localize predominantly to deep subcortical and periventricular white matter, regions supplied by small penetrating arterioles vulnerable to transient hypoperfusion during CSD.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression induces brief vasoconstriction and oligemia, leading to subtle blood–brain barrier disruption, endothelial changes, and focal axonal or myelin rarefaction manifesting as WMH on MRI.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Obtain detailed headache history; identify red flags.
2. Perform comprehensive neurological examination.
3. Review MRI: assess number (<3), size (<5 mm), morphology (punctate, non-enhancing).
4. If incidental and patient neurologically intact, no further work-up—provide reassurance.
5. Continue standard migraine prophylaxis/treatment as per guidelines.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Migraine WMH: punctate, non-enhancing, often frontal/deep; no surrounding edema.
• MS lesions: ovoid, periventricular “Dawson’s fingers,” may enhance during active demyelination.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Status migrainosus is a debilitating migraine attack lasting >72 hours. Key principles:
• Migraine pathophysiology involves trigeminovascular activation, cortical spreading depression, and release of inflammatory neuropeptides.
• In pregnancy, teratogenic risks (e.g., valproate) and uterotonic effects (ergot derivatives) limit pharmacologic choices.
• Corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone, dexamethasone) are potent anti-inflammatory agents that abort prolonged attacks by stabilizing vascular permeability and attenuating neurogenic inflammation without significant fetal harm when used short-term.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Methylprednisolone is the preferred rescue therapy for status migrainosus in late pregnancy. The American Headache Society (AHS) 2021 acute migraine guidelines endorse parenteral corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone 10 mg IV or equivalent methylprednisolone) for refractory, prolonged attacks (Level B evidence). Short courses cross the placenta minimally and have not been associated with congenital malformations or preterm labor when limited to 2–3 days. In contrast, ergot alkaloids induce uterine contractions and are absolutely contraindicated, while valproic acid carries a high teratogenic risk (neural tube defects rate >5%). Sumatriptan, although category C with some registry safety data, is used for abortive therapy—not as first-line rescue in status migrainosus—and lacks the anti-inflammatory profile of steroids necessary for prolonged attacks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Intranasal DHE
• Why incorrect: Dihydroergotamine is an ergot derivative causing potent uterine vasoconstriction and contraction—contraindicated in pregnancy.
• Misconception: Some believe intranasal route reduces systemic effects; uterine risk remains.
• Differentiator: Ergotamines are Category X vs. steroids Category C.

C. Valproic acid
• Why incorrect: High‐risk teratogen; neural tube defects, craniofacial abnormalities; absolutely avoided in pregnancy.
• Misconception: Broad antiepileptic utility implies safety; pregnancy risk profile overrides.
• Differentiator: Valproate has dose‐dependent teratogenicity (5–10% risk) vs. short‐term steroid safety.

D. Subcutaneous sumatriptan
• Why incorrect: While sumatriptan (Category C) has a pregnancy registry showing no major teratogenic signals, it lacks robust evidence for aborting a >72 hour migraine.
• Misconception: All triptans are equally acceptable in pregnancy for severe attacks; status migrainosus often requires anti-inflammatory therapy.
• Differentiator: Triptans target 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors to constrict cranial vessels but do not inhibit the prolonged inflammatory cascade as steroids do.

Methylprednisolone: dose 1 mg/kg IV once daily (up to 125 mg) for 2–3 days. Mechanism: inhibits NF-κB, reduces cytokine and prostaglandin synthesis, stabilizes blood–brain barrier permeability. Monitor for maternal hyperglycemia and fluid retention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Glossopharyngeal neuralgia (GN) is characterized by sudden, lancinating pain in the distribution of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and vagus nerve (CN X), often triggered by swallowing, chewing, or talking. CN IX conveys sensory input from the posterior tongue, tonsillar fossa, and carotid sinus; excessive afferent discharge can elicit vagally mediated syncope. Pathophysiologically, focal demyelination at the root entry zone—commonly due to vascular compression (e.g., posterior inferior cerebellar artery)—leads to ectopic, high-frequency impulses perceived as sharp pain. Differentiating primary (idiopathic) GN from secondary causes (tumors, vascular malformations) is critical because management ranges from sodium‐channel blockers to microvascular decompression or lesion resection.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI brain with high-resolution posterior fossa sequences is essential to exclude secondary etiologies before initiating GN-specific therapy. The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 classification (2018) mandates neuroimaging for all new-onset cranial neuralgias to rule out intracranial lesions (Level V evidence). The European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) guidelines on neuralgias (2012) endorse 1.5 T or 3 T MRI with 3D T2-weighted sequences (FIESTA/CISS) to visualize the glossopharyngeal nerve root exit zone and adjacent vascular loops (Level B). Cruccu et al. (Brain, 2016) demonstrated that such imaging identifies neurovascular compression in ~79% of GN cases, guiding surgical planning. CT and laryngoscopy lack sensitivity for posterior fossa pathology, and initiating carbamazepine without imaging risks masking treatable lesions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ENT & laryngoscope
– Laryngoscopy evaluates mucosal or structural oropharyngeal lesions but cannot detect deep posterior fossa pathology or neurovascular compression of CN IX. This reflects the misconception that throat pain always originates in the mucosa rather than neural structures.

C. CT head and neck
– CT offers poor soft-tissue contrast in the skull base and is insensitive to small nerve root lesions or vascular loops at the root entry zone. Relying on CT underestimates demyelination or posterior fossa tumors.

D. Carbamazepine trial
– Although carbamazepine is first-line pharmacotherapy for GN, guidelines require imaging to exclude secondary causes before symptom suppression. Empiric treatment can delay diagnosis of neoplasms or vascular malformations.

• GN may present with bradycardia or syncope due to carotid sinus hypersensitivity—ask about cardiac symptoms.
• Use 3D T2-weighted MRI sequences (FIESTA/CISS) to detect vascular compression with >80% sensitivity.

1. Equating glossopharyngeal neuralgia with odontogenic or ENT pathology and ordering laryngoscopy first.
2. Beginning carbamazepine empirically without imaging, which can mask underlying tumors or vascular malformations.

– Recommendation: 1.5 T/3 T MRI with high-resolution 3D sequences for visualization of nerve root entry zones and exclusion of neoplasms. (Level B evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The glossopharyngeal nerve emerges from the postolivary sulcus of the medulla, traverses the jugular foramen, and innervates the posterior pharynx and carotid sinus. Neurovascular compression typically occurs where the posterior inferior cerebellar artery loops around the root exit zone in the cerebellomedullary cistern.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Focal demyelination at the root entry zone—often from pulsatile vascular contact—induces ephaptic transmission between adjacent fibers, generating paroxysmal pain. Secondary mechanisms include mass effect from schwannomas or meningiomas at the jugular foramen.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: lancinating throat pain, triggers (swallowing, talking), syncope.
2. Physical exam: identify trigger zones in oropharynx; assess gag reflex.
3. Red flags: progressive deficits, weight loss.
4. MRI brain with high-resolution posterior fossa protocol.
5. If imaging negative: initiate carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine.
6. Refractory cases: consider microvascular decompression.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Obtain thin-slice (≤1 mm) 3D T2-weighted FIESTA/CISS and time-of-flight MRA sequences to delineate vascular loops compressing CN IX. Contrast-enhanced T1 sequences exclude enhancing lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine (sodium-channel blocker) is first-line: start 100 mg TID, titrate up to 600–1200 mg/day; monitor CBC and electrolytes. Oxcarbazepine is an alternative for intolerance; gabapentin and pregabalin are second-line.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Primary stabbing headache (PSH) is characterized by transient (“ice-pick”) head pains lasting 1–2 seconds, often in the distribution of the first division of the trigeminal nerve. Attacks may occur dozens to hundreds of times daily. It falls under the International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3) as an indomethacin-responsive primary headache. Unlike trigeminal neuralgia (paroxysms of electric shock–like pain) or paroxysmal hemicrania (longer attacks, autonomic features), PSH lacks autonomic signs and has ultra-short duration. Understanding trigeminal nociceptive pathways and prostaglandin-mediated sensitization underpins therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin, a nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor, is the established first-line agent for PSH. Its efficacy (complete or near-complete abolition of ice-pick pains in ~80–100% of reported cases) is supported by open-label series (Matharu et al., Cephalalgia 2005) and expert consensus in the AHS 2019 guidelines (Grade B evidence). ICHD-3 (2018) explicitly classifies PSH as indomethacin-responsive. The proposed mechanism involves reduction of prostaglandin E₂ in trigeminal nuclei, dampening peripheral and central sensitization. Starting dose is typically 25 mg TID, titrated to symptom resolution (up to 150 mg/day), with gastrointestinal protection (PPI) and renal monitoring.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lamictal
– Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant with sodium‐channel blocking properties. It has been used off‐label for PSH but requires slow titration (risk of rash, Stevens–Johnson syndrome) and lacks robust efficacy data (only small case series).
– Misconception: any episodic head pain may respond to lamotrigine.
– Differentiator: delayed onset (weeks) versus rapid indomethacin effect (days).

C. Topamax
– Topiramate, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is approved for migraine prophylaxis, not PSH. Studies in migraine show benefits over months, but it does not abort ice-pick pains.
– Misconception: broad migraine prophylactics work for all primary headaches.
– Differentiator: target migraine pathophysiology (cortical spreading depression) vs. prostaglandin-mediated sensitization in PSH.

D. Amitriptyline
– Tricyclic antidepressant effective for tension‐type headache and migraine prophylaxis at low doses. It has no role in PSH acute management and takes weeks to produce benefit.
– Misconception: first-line prophylactics cover all headache subtypes.
– Differentiator: anticholinergic side effects and slow titration vs. indomethacin’s rapid relief.

2. Assuming migraine prophylactics (e.g., topiramate) are effective for all primary headaches; PSH requires indomethacin.
3. Overlooking renal function monitoring with high-dose indomethacin.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Matharu M, et al. (Cephalalgia 2005): Prospective case series (n=30) showed 80% complete resolution of PSH with indomethacin within 5–7 days.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSH involves activation of pericranial nociceptors innervated by V₁ (ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve) with central propagation to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Prostaglandin-mediated peripheral sensitization in the trigeminal system leads to transient activation of nociceptive C-fibers; indomethacin’s COX inhibition reduces prostanoid synthesis, aborting pain spikes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Characterize attack (duration <2 s, stabbing quality).
2. Exclude red flags (neuroimaging if atypical features).
3. Trial indomethacin 25 mg TID; assess response in 5–7 days.
4. If intolerant or refractory, consider lamotrigine titrated to effect.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Neuroimaging is not routinely indicated unless red flags (e.g., focal deficits, systemic signs) are present; PSH is a clinical diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Indomethacin: start 25 mg TID, increase by 25 mg increments every 3 days to effect, max 150 mg/day. Monitor renal function and GI tolerability; use gastroprotective agents prophylactically.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Nummular headache is a primary headache disorder characterized by a fixed, coin-shaped area of scalp pain, typically 1–6 cm in diameter. According to ICHD-3 criteria (code 4.8), the pain is focal and persistent, often accompanied by cutaneous allodynia, hyperesthesia or hypoesthesia. Although rare, alopecia within the tender zone has been attributed to chronic neurogenic inflammation or microvascular alterations impairing follicular health. The underlying mechanism involves peripheral sensitization of terminal branches of trigeminal or occipital nerves, creating a neuropathic pain phenotype. Distinguishing nummular headache from tension-type headache or dermatologic scalp conditions is crucial, as management parallels neuropathic pain protocols rather than standard analgesic or anti-inflammatory approaches.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Gabapentin, an α2δ subunit ligand of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, reduces neurotransmitter release and diminishes peripheral nociceptive input. In a retrospective series of 53 patients (Caronna et al., J Headache Pain, 2022), 66% achieved ≥50% pain reduction on gabapentin (mean dose 1200 mg/day). Although randomized trials are lacking, multiple case reports (Pascual et al., Cephalalgia, 2013) demonstrate sustained relief with gabapentin, leading to its adoption as first-line therapy. The European Federation of Neurological Societies guideline on neuropathic pain (2010) grants level A recommendation to gabapentin for peripheral neuropathic syndromes, supporting its off-label use in nummular headache. By contrast, local anesthetics offer only transient relief, and no controlled data exist for topical steroids or tricyclics in this condition.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Topical corticosteroids
• Ineffective for neuropathic pain mechanisms; indicated for inflammatory dermatologic disorders (e.g., psoriasis, alopecia areata).
• Misconception: hair loss implies inflammatory scalp disease rather than neuropathic etiology.

C. Tricyclic antidepressants
• Amitriptyline modulates central pain pathways but has limited evidence in nummular headache; most data derive from migraine or generalized neuropathic pain.
• Side effects (anticholinergic, cardiotoxicity) often outweigh unproven benefit in focal scalp pain.

D. Local anesthesia
• Nerve blocks or lidocaine injections may transiently abolish pain (<4 hours) but lack prophylactic efficacy; require repeated procedures without sustained remission.
• Misconception: short-term relief equates to effective long-term management.

2. Alopecia in the painful region suggests chronic neurogenic inflammation; successful pain control often leads to hair regrowth.
3. Initiate gabapentin at 300 mg nightly, titrating by 300 mg every 2–3 days to target 900–1200 mg/day; monitor for sedation and adjust renal dosing as needed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing nummular headache as tension headache and prescribing NSAIDs alone, which fail to address peripheral neuropathic mechanisms.
2. Attributing localized alopecia to primary dermatologic disease and overusing topical steroids without evaluating neuropathic pain features.
3. Relying solely on nerve blocks without instituting prophylactic neuropathic agents, resulting in only transient relief.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3), International Headache Society, 2018 – Consensus-based criteria define nummular headache (4.8) as a peripheral neuropathic phenotype; level D (expert opinion).
2. American Academy of Neurology Guideline on Neuropathic Pain, 2014 – Recommends gabapentin as Level A treatment for peripheral neuropathic syndromes; supports off-label use in nummular headache.
3. Caronna A et al., “Gabapentin in Nummular Headache,” J Headache Pain, 2022 – Retrospective series (n=53) showing 66% response rate (≥50% pain reduction) with gabapentin (mean dose 1200 mg/day); level IV evidence.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Gabapentin binds the α2δ subunit of presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels, decreasing release of glutamate and substance P. Start at 300 mg once daily, increase by 300 mg every 2–3 days to a typical therapeutic range of 900–1200 mg/day in divided doses (max 2400 mg/day). Monitor for dizziness, somnolence and adjust for renal impairment (CrCl <60 mL/min). Pregabalin (75–300 mg/day) is an alternative if gabapentin is not tolerated.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by paroxysmal, lancinating facial pain in one or more branches (V1–V3) of the trigeminal nerve.
• Classical TN is usually due to vascular compression at the root entry zone, presenting after age 50, strictly unilateral, and without sensory deficits.
• Secondary (symptomatic) TN is caused by a structural lesion (e.g., multiple sclerosis plaque, cerebellopontine angle tumor) and often shows “red flags”: sensory abnormalities, bilateral pain, early onset (<40 years), involvement of V1, or abnormal trigeminal reflexes.
• The blink reflex (R1/R2) tests afferent V1 trigeminal fibers and efferent facial pathways; abnormalities localize to the pons, raising suspicion for demyelinating or mass lesions.

*(Word count: 116)*

Evidence-Based Analysis

Abnormal blink reflex testing is the single most predictive finding of a structural cause in TN. Cruccu et al. (2004, EFNS guidelines) demonstrated that an absent or delayed R1 response has a positive predictive value (PPV) > 90% and sensitivity ~75% for symptomatic TN. The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 (2018) classification lists abnormal trigeminal reflexes as a red flag warranting MRI. A structural lesion in the pons or at the root entry zone—whether demyelinating (MS) or neoplastic—disrupts the short-latency arc of the blink reflex, producing prolonged latencies or absent responses. Other clinical features (bilateral pain, sensory loss) have lower specificity or sensitivity. Current European Academy of Neurology (EAN, 2020) guidelines recommend routine trigeminal reflex testing in atypical TN to stratify the need for advanced neuroimaging.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Unilateral
• Classical TN is by definition unilateral; this does not distinguish classical from symptomatic forms.
• Misconception: Assuming unilateral pain excludes secondary TN—false, since early MS lesions or small tumors can initially be unilateral.

B. Old age
• Advancing age is associated with classical (vascular) TN, not structural lesions.
• Misconception: Believing that older patients are at higher risk for secondary causes—whereas younger onset (<40 years) is more worrisome.

D. Involving mainly V1
• Involvement of the ophthalmic division can occur in MS-related or space-occupying lesions, but its PPV for structural pathology (~50%) is far lower than blink reflex abnormalities.
• Misconception: Equating V1 pain alone with high risk; actually sensory deficits and reflex changes are more discriminating.

Clinical Pearls

– Always perform trigeminal reflex testing (blink reflex) in TN patients with atypical features (sensory loss, bilateral pain).
– A normal MRI with a normal blink reflex strongly supports classical TN; an abnormal blink reflex mandates high-resolution MRI (3 T FIESTA/CISS).
– In MS patients presenting with facial pain, disrupted blink reflex is an early marker of pontine demyelination.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

– Assuming older age excludes secondary TN; in reality, MS plaques may present late and tumors occur at all ages.
– Overreliance on pain distribution alone; sensory changes or reflex abnormalities are more specific than branch involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE NG59, 2019): “Obtain MRI with dedicated trigeminal sequences in TN patients who exhibit sensory deficits or abnormal trigeminal reflexes.” (Evidence level: Low-quality evidence, strong recommendation)
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN, 2020): Recommends routine blink reflex testing in atypical TN to guide neuroimaging decisions; abnormal results correlate with symptomatic etiologies (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The blink reflex involves:
• Afferent limb: V1 (supraorbital nerve) → trigeminal sensory nucleus in the pons
• Central interneurons in the pons connecting to the facial motor nucleus
• Efferent limb: facial nerve to orbicularis oculi muscle

Structural lesions at the root entry zone or pontine tegmentum impair this circuit, prolonging or abolishing the R1 response.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Classical TN arises from focal demyelination at the root entry zone due to pulsatile vascular compression (usually superior cerebellar artery). Secondary TN stems from intrinsic pontine pathology—e.g., MS plaques causing central demyelination or neoplastic infiltration—disrupting trigeminal conduction, especially reflex arcs.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: pain quality, triggers, duration, age at onset
2. Neurological exam: look for sensory loss, masseter weakness
3. Trigeminal reflex testing: blink reflex (R1/R2 latencies)
4. Neuroimaging: 3 T MRI with FIESTA/CISS and contrast if blink reflex is abnormal or exam shows deficits
5. Neuropathic pain workup: consider MS panels if demyelinating disease suspected

Neuroimaging Pearls

– Use high-resolution cisternal sequences (FIESTA, CISS) to detect neurovascular compression and small lesions.
– Contrast-enhanced T1‐weighted images delineate tumors or demyelinating plaques.
– Diffusion-weighted imaging can reveal acute pontine infarcts mimicking TN.

[Exam: Promotion 2019] • Cortical spreading depression (CSD): a wave of neuronal and glial depolarization underlying migraine aura.
• Aura phenomenology: positive visual symptoms (flashing lights), then negative visual deficits (hemianopia), and transient motor weakness in hemiplegic migraine.
• Differentiating stroke/TIA vs migraine aura: TIA produces negative deficits abruptly; migraine aura evolves gradually (>5 min) with positive phenomena and is followed by headache.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hemiplegic migraine (HM) meets ICHD-3 criteria (2018) for sporadic cases: reversible motor weakness plus at least one fully reversible visual symptom evolving over ≥5 minutes, lasting <72 hours, and headache. The patient’s positive visual phenomena (flashing lights), progressive homonymous hemianopia, and unilateral weakness over 45 minutes, followed by headache, are classic for HM. Advanced imaging (CT, CTA, DWI) is uniformly normal in HM, excluding acute infarction (Stroke Association 2018). By contrast, TIA typically yields sudden negative deficits without positive aura and may show perfusion abnormalities; an occipital seizure would have very brief (seconds-to-minutes) visual hallucinations with electrographic changes and postictal Todd’s paresis; PRES shows vasogenic edema on MRI.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
– TIA yields abrupt negative symptoms without preceding positive visual aura.
– Aura in TIA rarely includes flashing lights; headache is uncommon.
– TIA deficits resolve within 60 minutes and may show perfusion deficits on advanced imaging.

C. Occipital lobe seizure
– Ictal visual hallucinations are brief (seconds–minutes) and stereotyped; prolonged positive phenomena >30 minutes are unusual.
– Todd’s paralysis follows a seizure, not simultaneous with visual symptoms, and EEG would show ictal discharges.

D. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
– Presents with headache, seizures, visual loss, and altered mental status.
– MRI shows bilateral parieto-occipital vasogenic edema; CT/CTA/DWI would not all be normal.

2. Overreliance on CT alone—early ischemia can be DWI-occult; absence of infarct plus aura features favors migraine.

[Exam: Part I 2022] Medication‐overuse headache (MOH) arises when frequent use of acute headache medications paradoxically perpetuates headache.
• Primary headache disorders (e.g., migraine, tension‐type headache) may evolve into a chronic daily pattern if analgesics are overused, leading to central sensitization.
• Analgesic overuse is defined by ICHD-3 as ≥10 days/month for triptans, ergots or opioids, or ≥15 days/month for simple analgesics, sustained >3 months.
• MOH typically presents as a constant, dull or variable pain without migraine’s typical autonomic or migrainous features, and patients report transient relief only with further medication use.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medication overuse headache is diagnosed per ICHD-3 criteria when:
1. Headache present on ≥15 days/month in a patient with pre‐existing primary headache disorder.
2. Regular overuse of ≥1 acute/symptomatic headache medication for >3 months.
3. Headache resolves or reverts to its previous pattern within 2 months after discontinuation.

In this case, the patient’s shift from episodic migraines to daily headaches concurrent with high‐frequency ibuprofen/analgesic use, and transient improvement with more analgesics, is pathognomonic for MOH. Guidelines emphasize withdrawal of the offending agents as first‐line intervention (AHS Consensus 2019). Chronic migraine without overuse would still show migrainous features (photophobia, nausea), which are absent here.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Typical migraine
• Incorrect because migraines are episodic (4–72 h), associated with photophobia/phonophobia and nausea, and not daily. This option confuses episodic vs. chronic patterns.

C. Cluster headache
• Cluster attacks are short (15–180 min), severe, unilateral periorbital pains with ipsilateral autonomic signs (lacrimation, ptosis). They do not respond to simple analgesics and do not occur daily for months.

D. Tension-type headache
• Tension‐type headaches are bilateral, pressing/tightening, mild‐to‐moderate, and not typically aggravated by routine activity. They are less likely to improve markedly with analgesic overuse and do not evolve from migraine history with rebound features.

Clinical Pearls

• MOH prevalence is 1–2% in the general population and up to 50% in headache specialty clinics.
• Simple analgesics (NSAIDs) overuse (>15 days/month) can cause rebound headache; limit symptomatic meds to ≤10 days/month.
• Withdrawal of the offending agent often leads to headache improvement within 2 months; bridging therapies (e.g., prednisone taper) may ease withdrawal.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling chronic daily headache as chronic migraine without assessing medication use.
2. Assuming all rebound headaches present with migraine‐like features; MOH often lacks photophobia/nausea.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Headache Classification Committee of the International Headache Society (IHS). The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3), 2018: Defines MOH criteria—headache ≥15 days/month + regular overuse of acute meds for >3 months. Level of evidence: V (expert consensus).
2. American Headache Society Consensus Statement on MOH Management, 2019: Recommends abrupt discontinuation of offending drugs; consider bridging with NSAIDs or corticosteroids; initiate preventive therapy (e.g., topiramate, amitriptyline) within 1 month post‐withdrawal. Level of evidence: C (low‐quality evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic exposure to acute headache medications induces alterations in central pain modulatory systems—downregulation of serotonin receptors, enhanced glutamatergic transmission, and reduced endogenous opioid activity—leading to central sensitization and perpetuation of headache.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm headache frequency ≥15 days/month.
2. Document type and frequency of acute medication use (≥10 days/month triptans/ergots/opioids or ≥15 days/month simple analgesics for >3 months).
3. Exclude secondary causes (e.g., imaging if red flags present).
4. Advise prompt withdrawal of overused medication.
5. Offer bridging therapy (e.g., short‐course prednisone).
6. Initiate preventive therapy after withdrawal or within first month.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC) characterized by strictly unilateral, short-lived (2–30 min) headache attacks occurring >5 times/day, accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic signs. Key concepts:
• ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria require absolute responsiveness to indomethacin.
• Pathophysiology implicates trigeminal–autonomic reflex activation via the posterior hypothalamus and superior salivatory nucleus.
• Differentiation from cluster headache rests on attack duration, frequency, and indomethacin response.
Understanding these features underpins both diagnosis and first-line therapy. (122 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin, a nonselective COX-1/2 inhibitor, abolishes PH attacks in virtually all patients (relief within 24–72 h). The ICHD-3 (2018) and the European Headache Federation (EHF) consensus (2016) classify PH as indomethacin-responsive TAC (Level C evidence from open-label trials and case series). Cittadini & Goadsby (2002) reported 100% response in 24 patients. No randomized placebo-controlled trials exist, but multiple case series (n>200) confirm efficacy. Mechanistically, indomethacin may inhibit nitric oxide–mediated trigeminal activation. GI and renal adverse effects warrant co-prescription of a PPI and renal monitoring.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
– Incorrect: 5-HT₁B/₁D agonist effective in cluster headache/migraine acute treatment; PH attacks are too brief and indomethacin-specific.
– Misconception: All TACs respond to triptans (only cluster headache and hemicrania continua).

C. Verapamil
– Incorrect: First-line prophylactic for cluster headache; lacks efficacy in PH.
– Misconception: Calcium-channel blockers treat all TACs.

D. Carbamazepine
– Incorrect: Voltage-gated sodium-channel blocker for trigeminal neuralgia; no role in PH.
– Misconception: All unilateral facial pain responds to anticonvulsants.

• Always perform an indomethacin trial (start 25 mg TID, titrate to 150 mg/day) to confirm PH.
• Co-prescribe a proton-pump inhibitor and monitor renal function due to indomethacin toxicity.
• Attack frequency (>5/day) and short duration (<30 min) distinguish PH from cluster headache.

• Mistaking PH for cluster headache and using verapamil, delaying effective treatment.
• Assuming triptans abort PH attacks despite lack of response.
• Overlooking the absolute requirement for indomethacin responsiveness in ICHD-3.

• ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): Classifies PH as indomethacin-responsive TAC; mandates trial for diagnosis (Level C).
• European Headache Federation Consensus (2016): Recommends indomethacin 75–150 mg/day as first-line (Level C evidence).
• North American Headache Society Guidelines (2018): Advises indomethacin test before labeling PH (Grade B).

[Exam: Part I 2019] 1. Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) feature unilateral head pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic signs.
2. SUNCT (short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing) presents as very brief (5–240 s), frequent attacks (up to hundreds/day) with lacrimation and eye injection.
3. Effective treatment requires modulation of hyperexcitable trigeminal pathways; sodium-channel blockers like lamotrigine reduce abnormal neuronal firing and glutamate release.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lamotrigine is first-line for SUNCT based on open-label series and consensus guidelines. In a prospective study by Lambru et al. (2014), 62% of SUNCT patients achieved >50% reduction in attack frequency with lamotrigine (mean dose 200 mg/day; Level B evidence). The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) and American Headache Society consensus (2019) both recommend lamotrigine as first-line (Level C evidence for ICHD-3; Level B for AHS). Indomethacin, although highly effective in paroxysmal hemicrania, shows negligible benefit in SUNCT. Carbamazepine is established for trigeminal neuralgia, and topiramate for migraine prophylaxis—neither has robust efficacy data in SUNCT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Indomethacin
• Paroxysmal hemicrania responds dramatically to indomethacin; SUNCT does not.
• Misconception: all TACs are indomethacin-responsive.
• Key differentiator: SUNCT attacks <1 min vs hemicrania 2–30 min.

C. Carbamazepine
• First-line in trigeminal neuralgia (shock-like pains, trigger zones), not SUNCT.
• Misconception: all short facial pains represent neuralgia.
• Key differentiator: SUNCT has autonomic signs and no trigger zones.

D. Topiramate
• Proven for migraine prophylaxis (attacks 4–72 h), lacks efficacy in SUNCT.
• Misconception: migraine preventives apply to all headache types.
• Key differentiator: SUNCT attack pattern and parasympathetic features.

• An indomethacin trial is diagnostic for paroxysmal hemicrania (complete resolution distinguishes it from SUNCT).
• Titrate lamotrigine slowly (start 25 mg/day) to minimize risk of rash/Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

• Misdiagnosing SUNCT as trigeminal neuralgia and using carbamazepine—overlook autonomic signs.
• Empiric indomethacin trial without considering attack duration/frequency leads to misclassification of TAC subtype.

• ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): classifies SUNCT/SUNA and recommends lamotrigine first-line (Level C).
• American Headache Society consensus (2019): endorses lamotrigine for SUNCT based on case series (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Attacks arise from activation of trigeminal nerve V1 afferents projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis; parasympathetic efferents via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion produce lacrimation and conjunctival injection.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hyperexcitability of trigeminal nociceptive neurons and disinhibition of the trigeminal-autonomic reflex cause brief, frequent pain attacks with parasympathetic activation. Lamotrigine stabilizes neuronal sodium channels and reduces excitatory neurotransmission.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Assess headache duration (<1 min), frequency (>20/day), autonomic signs.
2. Exclude secondary causes with brain MRI.
3. Administer indomethacin trial: if complete response → paroxysmal hemicrania; if no response → SUNCT.
4. Initiate and titrate lamotrigine.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI is typically normal in SUNCT but necessary to rule out structural lesions (e.g., pituitary adenoma, posterior fossa pathology).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Lamotrigine: initiate at 25 mg once daily, increase by 25 mg/week to 200–400 mg/day. Monitor for dermatologic reactions and counsel on slow titration.
